newsitem.title: USA: US West Coast products idle on volatile NYMEX.
newsitem.headline: US West Coast products idle on volatile NYMEX.

text.p: U.S. West Coast product prices idled late on Thursday, with activity fading because of volatile NYMEX values.
Heating oil for September delivery led the rally with a 1.63-cent rise to 63.67 cents a gallon. Front-month gasoline finished 1.39 cents higher at 63.72 cents
Low heating oil stocks ahead of winter demand and fears of further hurricanes in the Carribean lifted the market.
American Petroleum Institute showed a 463,000 barrel fall in distillate stocks last week.
Locally, traders heard Mobil was looking to buy conventional grade gasoline because of ongoing problems with a fluid catalytic cracker in Torrance, California.
Mobil declined comment and left traders wondering how long the widely-rumoured problem would continue.
Crude players said the alleged trouble left Mobil with excess heavy crude.
Even players who disputed the rumour said speculation that Mobil would buy forced traders to hold their positions.
Los Angeles regular unleaded was seen unchanged between 66.50 and 67.50 cents early on Thursday.
Premium traded at a 7.50 cent premium, as more buyers came in on reports of the refinery units.
Unocal Corp in Northern California continued to return to normal production levels after shutting a crude unit last week for repairs, traders said.
And Cheveron was rumoured to begin shutting a unit in early September at its Los Angeles refinery.
Offers for CARB gasoline in Los Angeles stayed at 71.50 cents. Bids were nearly invisibile because of NYMEX volatility, but they stood notionally at 70 cents.
Distillates remained notionally unchanged on Thursday.
